isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: SHEPPARD M-SERIES - PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE - INPUT SHAFT SEAL REPLACEMENT AFTER JULY 1990

svcproc.title: INPUT SHAFT SEAL REPLACEMENT AFTER JULY 1990

svcprocinfo.para: Current Production After July 1990 - input shaft bearing cap cover will have a grease fitting ( Figure 19).

important.para: Do not remove the steering gear for this procedure.

svcprocinfo.para: Before a seal can be replaced, you must identify the manufacturing date of the steering gear. This can be done by following the steering gear identification procedure.

warning.para: Failure to replace all seals, cotter pins, retainers and critical fasteners may result in an accident, injury or death.

step1.para: Park the vehicle on a clean, dry, solid surface, preferably concrete. Set the parking brake and block the wheels. Place the transmission in neutral.
Tilt the hood or cab.
Loosen and remove the pinch bolt on the lower end yoke of the steering shaft.
Remove the lower yoke from the steering gear input shaft. If necessary, secure the steering shaft so it will not be in the way.

important.para: Do not pull the slip shaft out of the steering shaft. This would require re-phasing at time of installation.

step1.para: Place the drain pan under the power steering gear. Draining the system is not necessary, but some fluid will be lost.
Use a ratchet and 15 or 16 mm socket to loosen and remove the 4 bearing cap cover bolts and cover ( Figure 20).

figure.caption: Figure 21. Remove Bearing Cap Cover Bolts

caution.para: Do not turn the input shaft during repairs. Turning the shaft or mixing components will cause damage to the bearing cap and actuating shaft assembly.

important.para: The thrust washer may stick to the bearing cap cover. If this happens, re-install the thrust washer in the steering gear ( Figure 21 and Figure 22).

figure.caption: Figure 22. Re-Install Thrust Washer in Steering Gear
Figure 23. Re-Install Thrust Washer in Steering Gear

step1.para: Pry the salt seal out of the bearing cap cover with a screwdriver ( Figure 23).

figure.caption: Figure 24. Pry Salt Seal Out of Bearing Cap Cover

step1.para: Lightly tap a 1 inch socket and short extension to remove the input shaft seal and backup washer. Discard the seals and backup washer ( Figure 24).

figure.caption: Figure 25. Remove Input Shaft Seal and Back-Up Washer

warning.para: Wear safety glasses and use light hammer blows to prevent damage to the extension.

step1.para: Remove the bearing cap cover O-ring and discard.
Clean the bearing cap cover with an approved solvent and blow it dry with low pressure air.

warning.para: Always wear safety glasses and use low pressure air only to clean parts.

step1.para: Place the cover on a work bench with it lying on the outer surface. Install the back-up washer. Make sure it is lying flat on the shoulder of the seal bore ( Figure 25).
Install the input shaft seal in the cover using the 1 inch socket as a driver. Make sure the lip of the seal is facing inward. Drive the seal in until it bottoms on the back-up washer ( Figure 26).
Install a new cover O-ring and cover the shaft with white grease or a similar product ( Figure 27).
Re-install the bearing cap cover on the bearing cap ( Figure 28).

caution.para: Do not damage the input shaft seal during installation.

step1.para: Install the four bearing cap cover bolts and tighten to 53 to 63 ft-lbs. (72 to 85 Nm) ( Figure 29).

figure.caption: Figure 30. Install Bearing Cap Cover Bolts

step1.para: Install the salt seal in the bearing cap cover. Push the salt seal in with your fingers until it is flush with the outer surface of the cover. Make sure the lip of the seal is facing out toward the splined shaft ( Figure 30).
Slip the lower end yoke of the steering shaft onto the input shaft so the pinch bolt hole lines up with the whistle notch in the input shaft.
Re-install the pinch bolt and nut and tighten. Refer to GROUP 05 - STEERING in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for the proper torque value for the vehicle and type of column being serviced.
Use the hand grease gun to pump a small amount of grease into the grease fitting until grease can be seen coming out around the salt seal.
Check the fluid level in the power steering reservoir and make sure that it is full.
Start the vehicle and allow it to idle. Check for leaks.
Shut the unit off after checking for leaks and check fluid level.
Clean any fluid from the power steering gear and remove the drain pan.
Lower the cab or hood.
